greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Sequence generated from A014577, the dragon curve.
comment: Rows of A164281 tend to A166242. Subsets of the first 2^n terms can be parsed into a binomial frequency of powers of 2; for example, the first 16 terms has as frequency of (1, 4, 6, 4, 1): (one 1, four 2's, six 4's, four 8's, and one 16.).
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = -1..8191
Index entries for sequences related to binary expansion of n
formula: As a recursive string in subsets of 2^n terms, the next subset = twice each term of current string, reversed, and appended.
example: By recursion, given the first four terms: (1, 2, 4, 2); reverse, double, and append to (1, 2, 4, 2) getting (1, 2, 4, 2, 4, 8, 4, 2,...).
mathematica: FoldList[If[EvenQ[((#2 + 1)/2^IntegerExponent[#2 + 1, 2] - 1)/2], 2 #1, #1/2] &, 1, Range[0, 89]] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jul 29 2017, after _Jean-François Alcover_ at A014577 *)
program: ;; Because definec does not work well with offset -1, we define an offset-0 based version of recurrence:
;; which the offset -1 version will invoke:
;; Scheme-code for A000035 and A000265 given under respective entries.
results.author: _Gary W. Adamson_, Oct 10 2009
